DataElement.preferredName: Lung Tumor T Stage Four Present Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type or extent of the primary tumor present in Stage T4 lung cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Lung Tumor T Stage Four Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to a Stage T4 lung tumor (T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site) present (being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).:A natural number greater than 3 and less than 5 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of three and one.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).
A natural number greater than 3 and less than 5 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of three and one.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type or extent of the primary tumor present in Stage T4 lung cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: Separate tumor nodules in a different ipsilateral lobe
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Separate tumor nodules in a different ipsilateral lobe

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Separate tumor nodules in a different ipsilateral lobe
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Separate tumor nodules in a different ipsilateral lobe
A ridge or ridge-like structure.  In humans it usually refers to the trachea.  The carina of trachea is part of the lowest tracheal cartilage which is placed between the orifices of the two bronchi.

Concepts.definition: A ridge or ridge-like structure.  In humans it usually refers to the trachea.  The carina of trachea is part of the lowest tracheal cartilage which is placed between the orifices of the two bronchi.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of the ring-shaped bony structures that constitute the spinal column and surround the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: Any of thirty-three ring-shaped structures that form the vertebral column which surrounds and protects the spinal cord. Each vertebra consists of a bony body with its superior and inferior articular surfaces covered by hyaline cartilage. The body includes the centrum anteriorly and vertebral arch posteriorly. The articular surfaces of the vertebrae are connected by a fibrocartilaginous intervertebral disc.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fibrocartilaginous, mucous-lined tube passing from the larynx to the bronchi.

Concepts.definition: The fibrocartilaginous, mucous-lined tube passing from the larynx to the bronchi.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated NCIt definition to most current version. mc 2/15/13

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A hollow muscular organ which receives the blood from the veins and propels it into the arteries. It is divided by a musculomembranous septum into two halves -- right or venous and left or arterial -- each of which consists of a receiving chamber (atrium) and an ejecting chamber (ventricle). SYN cor, coeur.

Concepts.definition: A hollow organ located slightly to the left of the middle portion of the chest. It is composed of muscle and it is divided by a septum into two sides: the right side which receives de-oxygenated blood from the body and the left side which sends newly oxygenated blood to the body. Each side is composed of two chambers: the atrium (receiving blood) and ventricle (ejecting blood).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (mee-dee-a-STYE-num) The area between the lungs. The organs in this area include the heart and its large blood vessels, the trachea, the esophagus, the bronchi, and lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: An anatomic site along the midline and under the sternum that contains the heart and pericardium, the bases of the great vessels, the trachea and bronchi, esophagus, thymus, lymph nodes, thoracic duct, phrenic and vagus nerves, and other structures and tissues.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
